 I disagreed and said the probability of a shark attack is still 1 in 1 million whether you have 1 person or 1 million people. 1 million people in the ocean once is the same as 1 person in the ocean 1 million times. The probability of that 1 person getting attacked is the same whether it's the first time they enter the ocean or the 1 millionth time.
 
 Am I right? If so, is there a theory or principle I can reference to explain this to him? If I'm wrong, why?

 I know what you're saying makes sense, but it just seems wrong for some reason.

1 million people in the ocean at one time would be the same a one person in the ocean 1 million times (if that were possible).
 
 The chance a specific individual being attacked is 1/1,000,000. If that person goes into the ocean 1,000,000 times then the probability that they would be attacked one or more times would be 1 minus the chance of never being attacked, which is 1 minus 0.999999^1,000,000 = 0.632.
 
 This is the same as having 1,000,000 people in the ocean at the same time 1 minus probability of no-one being attacked, or 0.632 chance of 1 or more of them being attacked.
 
 Your room-mate is correct that the chance of a shark attack is greater if there are more people, though the chance for a specific individual is the same.
 
 It's like asking if the chance of rolling a 6 on a standard die is 1/6, then what is the chance of rolling at least one six if you roll 6 dice. It is 1 minus the chance of not rolling a six on any of them. Which is 1 minus '5/6 to the power 6', or 1 - 0.335 = 0.665. So the chances of rolling a six on a specific die (out of the 6) is still 1/6, but the chance of rolling a 6 one any one or more of the 6 dice is around 2/3.
